sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: What a state I am in ! Before he came , nothing mattered ; I felt so free . But now that he has come , goodness knows from where , my heart is filled with his dear self , and my home will be no home to me when he leaves . Doctor , do you think he —

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: If there 's life in his fate , then he will live long . But what the medical scriptures say , it seems —

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Great heavens , what ?

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: The scriptures have it : “ Bile or palsey , cold or gout spring all alike . ”

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Oh , get along , do n't fling your scriptures at me ; you only make me more anxious ; tell me what I can do .

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: Taking snuffThe patient needs the most scrupulous care .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: That 's true ; but tell me how .

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: I have already mentioned , on no account must he be let out of doors . MADHAV Poor child , it is very hard to keep him indoors all day long .

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: What else can you do ? The autumn sun and the damp are both very bad for the little fellow — for the scriptures have it : /* “ In wheezing , swoon or in nervous fret , In jaundice or leaden eyes — ” */

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Never mind the scriptures , please . Eh , then we must shut the poor thing up . Is there no other method ?

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: None at all : for , “ In the wind and in the sun — ”

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: What will your “ in this and in that ” do for me now ? Why do n't you let them alone and come straight to the point ? What 's to be done then ? Your system is very , very hard for the poor boy ; and he is so quiet too with all his pain and sickness . It tears my heart to see him wince , as he takes your medicine .

sp.speaker: PHYSICIAN
sp.p: effect . That 's why the sage Chyabana observes : “ In medicine as in good advices , the least palatable ones are the truest . ” Ah , well ! I must be trotting now .Exit

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Well , I 'm jiggered , there 's Gaffer now .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Why , why , I wo n't bite you .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , but you are a devil to send children off their heads .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: But you are n't a child , and you 've no child in the house ; why worry then ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Oh , but I have brought a child into the house .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Indeed , how so ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: You remember how my wife was dying to adopt a child ?

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Yes , but that 's an old story ; you did n't like the idea .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: You know , brother , how hard all this getting money in has been . That somebody else 's child would sail in and waste all this money earned with so much trouble — Oh , I hated the idea . But this boy clings to my heart in such a queer sort of way —

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: So that 's the trouble ! and your money goes all for him and feels jolly lucky it does go at all .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Formerly , earning was a sort of passion with me ; I simply could n't help working for money . Now , I make money and as I know it is all for this dear boy , earning becomes a joy to me .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Ah , well , and where did you pick him up ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: He is the son of a man who was a brother to my wife by village ties . He has had no mother since infancy ; and now the other day he lost his father as well .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Poor thing : and so he needs me all the more .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: The doctor says all the organs of his little body are at loggerheads with each other , and there is n't much hope for his life . There is only one way to save him and that is to keep him out of this autumn wind and sun . But you are such a terror ! What with this game of yours at your age , too , to get children out of doors !

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: God bless my soul ! So I 'm already as bad as autumn wind and sun , eh ! But , friend , I know something , too , of the game of keeping them indoors . When my day 's work is over I am coming in to make friends with this child of yours .Exit

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Uncle , I say , Uncle !

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Hullo ! Is that you , Amal ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: May n't I be out of the courtyard at all ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , my dear , no .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: See , there where Auntie grinds lentils in the quirn , the squirrel is sitting with his tail up and with his wee hands he 's picking up the broken grains of lentils and crunching them . Ca n't I run up there ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , my darling , no .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Wish I were a squirrel !— it would be lovely . Uncle , why wo n't you let me go about ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Doctor says it 's bad for you to be out .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How can the doctor know ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: What a thing to say ! The doctor can n't know and he reads such huge books !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Does his book-learning tell him everything ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Of course , do n't you know ! AMALWith a sighAh , I am so stupid ! I do n't read books .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Now , think of it ; very , very learned people are all like you ; they are never out of doors .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Are n't they really ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , how can they ? Early and late they toil and moil at their books , and they 've eyes for nothing else . Now , my little man , you are going to be learned when you grow up ; and then you will stay at home and read such big books , and people will notice you and say , “ he 's a wonder . ”

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , no , Uncle ; I beg of you by your dear feet — I do n't want to be learned , I wo n't .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Dear , dear ; it would have been my saving if I could have been learned .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , I would rather go about and see everything that there is .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Listen to that ! See ! What will you see , what is there so much to see ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: See that far-away hill from our window — I often long to go beyond those hills and right away .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Oh , you silly ! As if there 's nothing more to be done but just get up to the top of that hill and away ! Eh ! You do n't talk sense , my boy . Now listen , since that hill stands there upright as a barrier , it means you can n't get beyond it . Else , what was the use in heaping up so many large stones to make such a big affair of it , eh !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Uncle , do you think it is meant to prevent your crossing over ? It seems to me because the earth can n't speak it raises its hands into the sky and beckons . And those who live far and sit alone by their windows can see the signal . But I suppose the learned people —

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , they do n't have time for that sort of nonsense . They are not crazy like you .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do you know , yesterday I met someone quite as crazy as I am .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Gracious me , really , how so ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: He had a bamboo staff on his shoulder with a small bundle at the top , and a brass pot in his left hand , and an old pair of shoes on ; he was making for those hills straight across that meadow there . I called out to him and asked , “ Where are you going ? ” He answered , “ I do n't know , anywhere ! ” I asked again , “ Why are you going ? ” He said , “ I 'm going out to seek work . ” Say , Uncle , have you to seek work ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Of course I have to . There 's many about looking for jobs .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How lovely ! I 'll go about , like them too , finding things to do .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Suppose you seek and do n't find . Then —

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Would n't that be jolly ? Then I should go farther ! I watched that man slowly walking on with his pair of worn out shoes . And when he got to where the water flows under the fig tree , he stopped and washed his feet in the stream . Then he took out from his bundle some gram-flour , moistened it with water and began to eat . Then he tied up his bundle and shouldered it again ; tucked up his cloth above his knees and crossed the stream . I 've asked Auntie to let me go up to the stream , and eat my gram-flour just like him .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: And what did your Auntie say to that ?

lg.l: Auntie said , “ Get well and then I 'll take you over there . ”
Please , Uncle , when shall I get well ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: It wo n't be long , dear .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Really , but then I shall go right away the moment I 'm well again .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: And where will you go ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , I will walk on , crossing so many streams , wading through water . Everybody will be asleep with their doors shut in the heat of the day and I will tramp on and on seeking work far , very far .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: I see ! I think you had better be getting well first ; then —

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But then you wo n't want me to be learned , will you , Uncle ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: What would you rather be then ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I can n't think of anything just now ; but I 'll tell you later on .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Very well . But mind you , you are n't to call out and talk to strangers again .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But I love to talk to strangers !

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Suppose they had kidnapped you ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: That would have been splendid ! But no one ever takes me away . They all want me to stay in here .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: I am off to my work — but , darling , you wo n't go out , will you ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , I wo n't . But , Uncle , you 'll let me be in this room by the roadside .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Curds , curds , good nice curds .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Curdseller , I say , Curdseller .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Why do you call me ? Will you buy some curds ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How can I buy ? I have no money .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: What a boy ! Why call out then ? Ugh ! What a waste of time .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I would go with you if I could .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: With me ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Yes , I seem to feel homesick when I hear you call from far down the road .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Lowering his yoke-poleWhatever are you doing here , my child ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: The doctor says I 'm not to be out , so I sit here all day long .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: My poor child , whatever has happened to you ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I can n't tell . You see I am not learned , so I do n't know what 's the matter with me . Say , Dairyman , where do you come from ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: From our village .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Your village ? Is it very far ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Our village lies on the river Shamli at the foot of the Panch-mura hills .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Panch-mura hills ! Shamli river ! I wonder . I may have seen your village . I can n't think when though !

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Have you seen it ? Been to the foot of those hills ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Never . But I seem to remember having seen it . Your village is under some very old big trees , just by the side of the red road — is n't that so ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: That 's right , child .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And on the slope of the hill cattle grazing .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: How wonderful ! Are n't there cattle grazing in our village ! Indeed , there are !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And your women with red sarees fill their pitchers from the river and carry them on their heads .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Good , that 's right . Women from our dairy village do come and draw their water from the river ; but then it is n't everyone who has a red saree to put on . But , my dear child , surely you must have been there for a walk some time .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Really , Dairyman , never been there at all . But the first day doctor lets me go out , you are going to take me to your village .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: I will , my child , with pleasure .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And you 'll teach me to cry curds and shoulder the yoke like you and walk the long , long road ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Dear , dear , did you ever ? Why should you sell curds ? No , you will read big books and be learned .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , I never want to be learned — I 'll be like you and take my curds from the village by the red road near the old banyan tree , and I will hawk it from cottage to cottage . Oh , how do you cry — “ Curd , curd , good nice curd ! ” Teach me the tune , will you ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Dear , dear , teach you the tune ; what an idea !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Please do . I love to hear it . I can n't tell you how queer I feel when I hear you cry out from the bend of that road , through the line of those trees ! Do you know I feel like that when I hear the shrill cry of kites from almost the end of the sky ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Dear child , will you have some curds ? Yes , do .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But I have no money .

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: No , no , no , do n't talk of money ! You 'll make me so happy if you have a little curds from me .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Say , have I kept you too long ?

sp.speaker: DAIRYMAN
sp.p: Not a bit ; it has been no loss to me at all ; you have taught me how to be happy selling curds .Exit

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: IntoningCurds , curds , good nice curds — from the dairy village — from the country of the Panch-mura hills by the Shamli bank . Curds , good curds ; in the early morning the women make the cows stand in a row under the trees and milk them , and in the evening they turn the milk into curds . Curds , good curds . Hello , there 's the watchman on his rounds . Watchman , I say , come and have a word with me .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: What 's all this row you are making ? Are n't you afraid of the likes of me ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , why should I be ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Suppose I march you off then ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Where will you take me to ? Is it very far , right beyond the hills ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Suppose I march you straight to the King ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: To the King ! Do , will you ? But the doctor wo n't let me go out . No one can ever take me away . I 've got to stay here all day long .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Doctor wo n't let you , poor fellow ! So I see ! Your face is pale and there are dark rings round your eyes . Your veins stick out from your poor thin hands .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Wo n't you sound the gong , Watchman ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Time has not yet come .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How curious ! Some say time has not yet come , and some say time has gone by ! But surely your time will come the moment you strike the gong !

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: That 's not possible ; I strike up the gong only when it is time .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Yes , I love to hear your gong . When it is midday and our meal is over , Uncle goes off to his work and Auntie falls asleep reading her Râmayana , and in the courtyard under the shadow of the wall our doggie sleeps with his nose in his curled up tail ; then your gong strikes out , “ Dong , dong , dong ! ” Tell me why does your gong sound ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: My gong sounds to tell the people , Time waits for none , but goes on forever .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Where , to what land ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: That none knows .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Then I suppose no one has ever been there ! Oh , I do wish to fly with the time to that land of which no one knows anything .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: All of us have to get there one day , my child .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Have I too ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Yes , you too !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But doctor wo n't let me out .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: One day the doctor himself may take you there by the hand .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: He wo n't ; you do n't know him . He only keeps me in .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: One greater than he comes and lets us free .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: When will this great doctor come for me ? I can n't stick in here any more .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Should n't talk like that , my child .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No . I am here where they have left me — I never move a bit . But when your gong goes off , dong , dong , dong , it goes to my heart . Say , Watchman ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Yes , my dear .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Say , what 's going on there in that big house on the other side , where there is a flag flying high up and the people are always going in and out ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Oh , there ? That 's our new Post Office .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Post Office ? Whose ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Whose ? Why , the King 's surely !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do letters come from the King to his office here ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Of course . One fine day there may be a letter for you in there .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: A letter for me ? But I am only a little boy .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: The King sends tiny notes to little boys .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , how lovely ! When shall I have my letter ? How do you guess he 'll write to me ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Otherwise why should he set his Post Office here right in front of your open window , with the golden flag flying ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But who will fetch me my King 's letter when it comes ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: The King has many postmen . Do n't you see them run about with round gilt badges on their chests ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Well , where do they go ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Oh , from door to door , all through the country .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I 'll be the King 's postman when I grow up .

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! Postman , indeed ! Rain or shine , rich or poor , from house to house delivering letters — that 's very great work !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: That 's what I 'd like best . What makes you smile so ? Oh , yes , your work is great too . When it is silent everywhere in the heat of the noonday , your gong sounds , Dong , dong , dong ,— and sometimes when I wake up at night all of a sudden and find our lamp blown out , I can hear through the darkness your gong slowly sounding , Dong , dong , dong !

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: There 's the village headman ! I must be off . If he catches me gossiping with you there 'll be a great to do .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: The headman ? Whereabouts is he ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Right down the road there ; see that huge palm-leaf umbrella hopping along ? That 's him !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I suppose the King 's made him our headman here ?

sp.speaker: WATCHMAN
sp.p: Made him ? Oh , no ! A fussy busy-body ! He knows so many ways of making himself unpleasant that everybody is afraid of him . It 's just a game for the likes of him , making trouble for everybody . I must be off now ! Must n't keep work waiting , you know ! I 'll drop in again to-morrow morning and tell you all the news of the town .Exit

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: It would be splendid to have a letter from the King every day . I 'll read them at the window . But , oh ! I can n't read writing . Who 'll read them out to me , I wonder ! Auntie reads her Râmayana ; she may know the King 's writing . If no one will , then I must keep them carefully and read them when I 'm grown up . But if the postman can n't find me ? Headman , Mr. Headman , may I have a word with you ?

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: Who is yelling after me on the highway ? Oh , you wretched monkey !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: You 're the headman . Everybody minds you . HEADMANLooking pleasedYes , oh yes , they do ! They must !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do the King 's postmen listen to you ?

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: They 've got to . By Jove , I 'd like to see —

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Will you tell the postman it 's Amal who sits by the window here ?

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: What 's the good of that ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: In case there 's a letter for me .

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: A letter for you ! Whoever 's going to write to you ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: If the King does .

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! What an uncommon little fellow you are ! Ha ! ha ! the King indeed , are n't you his bosom friend , eh ! You have n't met for a long while and the King is pining , I am sure . Wait till to-morrow and you 'll have your letter .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Say , Headman , why do you speak to me in that tone of voice ? Are you cross ?

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: Upon my word ! Cross , indeed ! You write to the King ! Madhav is devilish swell nowadays . He 'd made a little pile ; and so kings and padishahs are everyday talk with his people . Let me find him once and I 'll make him dance . Oh , you snipper-snapper ! I 'll get the King 's letter sent to your house — indeed I will !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , no , please do n't trouble yourself about it .

sp.speaker: HEADMAN
sp.p: And why not , pray ! I 'll tell the King about you and he wo n't be very long . One of his footmen will come along presently for news of you . Madhav 's impudence staggers me . If the King hears of this , that 'll take some of his nonsense out of him .Exit

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Who are you walking there ? How your anklets tinkle ! Do stop a while , dear , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: I have n't a moment to spare ; it is already late !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I see , you do n't wish to stop ; I do n't care to stay on here either .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: You make me think of some late star of the morning ! Whatever 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I do n't know ; the doctor wo n't let me out .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: Ah me ! Do n't then ! Should listen to the doctor . People 'll be cross with you if you 're naughty . I know , always looking out and watching must make you feel tired . Let me close the window a bit for you .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , do n't , only this one 's open ! All the others are shut . But will you tell me who you are ? Do n't seem to know you .

sp.speaker: GIRL
sp.p: I am Sudha .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: What Sudha ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: Do n't you know ? Daughter of the flower-seller here .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: What do you do ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: I gather flowers in my basket .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , flower gathering ! That is why your feet seem so glad and your anklets jingle so merrily as you walk . Wish I could be out too . Then I would pick some flowers for you from the very topmost branches right out of sight .

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: Would you really ? Do you know more about flowers than I ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Yes , I do , quite as much . I know all about Champa of the fairy tale and his seven brothers . If only they let me , I 'll go right into the dense forest where you can n't find your way . And where the honey-sipping hummingbird rocks himself on the end of the thinnest branch , I will flower out as a champa . Would you be my sister Parul ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: You are silly ! How can I be sister Parul when I am Sudha and my mother is Sasi , the flower-seller ? I have to weave so many garlands a day . It would be jolly if I could lounge here like you !

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: What would you do then , all the day long ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: I could have great times with my doll Benay the bride , and Meni the pussycat and — but I say it is getting late and I must n't stop , or I wo n't find a single flower .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , wait a little longer ; I do like it so !

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: Ah , well — now do n't you be naughty . Be good and sit still and on my way back home with the flowers I 'll come and talk with you .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And you 'll let me have a flower then ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: No , how can I ? It has to be paid for .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I 'll pay when I grow up — before I leave to look for work out on the other side of that stream there .

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: Very well , then .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And you 'll come back when you have your flowers ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: You will , really ?

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: Yes , I will .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: You wo n't forget me ? I am Amal , remember that .

sp.speaker: SUDHA
sp.p: I wo n't forget you , you 'll see .Exit

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Say , brothers , where are you all off to ? Stop here a little .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: We 're off to play .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: What will you play at , brothers ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: We 'll play at being ploughmen . FIRST BOYShowing a stickThis is our ploughshare .

sp.speaker: SECOND BOY
sp.p: We two are the pair of oxen .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And you 're going to play the whole day ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Yes , all day long .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And you 'll come back home in the evening by the road along the river bank ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do you pass our house on your way home ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: You come out to play with us , yes do .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Doctor wo n't let me out .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Doctor ! Suppose the likes of you mind the doctor . Let 's be off ; it is getting late .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do n't . Why not play on the road near this window ? I could watch you then .

sp.speaker: THIRD BOY
sp.p: What can we play at here ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: With all these toys of mine lying about . Here you are , have them . I can n't play alone . They are getting dirty and are of no use to me .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: How jolly ! What fine toys ! Look , here 's a ship . There 's old mother Jatai ; say , chaps , ai n't he a gorgeous sepoy ? And you 'll let us have them all ? You do n't really mind ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No , not a bit ; have them by all means .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: You do n't want them back ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , no , I sha n't want them .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Say , wo n't you get a scolding for this ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No one will scold me . But will you play with them in front of our door for a while every morning ? I 'll get you new ones when these are old .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Oh , yes , we will . Say , chaps , put these sepoys into a line . We 'll play at war ; where can we get a musket ? Oh , look here , this bit of reed will do nicely . Say , but you 're off to sleep already .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm sleepy . I do n't know , I feel like it at times . I have been sitting a long while and I 'm tired ; my back aches .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: It 's only early noon now . How is it you 're sleepy ? Listen ! The gong 's sounding the first watch .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Yes , dong , dong , dong , it tolls me to sleep .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: We had better go then . We 'll come in again to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: I want to ask you something before you go . You are always out — do you know of the King 's postmen ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Yes , quite well .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Who are they ? Tell me their names .

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: One 's Badal , another 's Sarat . There 's so many of them .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Do you think they will know me if there 's a letter for me ?

sp.speaker: BOYS
sp.p: Surely , if your name 's on the letter they will find you out .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: When you call in to-morrow morning , will you bring one of them along so that he 'll know me ?

div.head: ACT II

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Ca n't I go near the window to-day , Uncle ? Would the doctor mind that too ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Yes , darling , you see you 've made yourself worse squatting there day after day .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Oh , no , I do n't know if it 's made me more ill , but I always feel well when I 'm there .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: No , you do n't ; you squat there and make friends with the whole lot of people round here , old and young , as if they are holding a fair right under my eaves — flesh and blood wo n't stand that strain . Just see — your face is quite pale .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Uncle , I fear my fakir 'll pass and not see me by the window .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Your fakir , whoever 's that ?

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: He comes and chats to me of the many lands where he 's been . I love to hear him .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: How 's that ? I do n't know of any fakirs .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: This is about the time he comes in . I beg of you , by your dear feet , ask him in for a moment to talk to me here .

div.stage: GAFFER Enters in a FAKIR 'S Guise

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: There you are . Come here , Fakir , by my bedside .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Upon my word , but this is —

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Winking hardI am the fakir .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: It beats my reckoning what you 're not .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Where have you been this time , Fakir ?

sp.speaker: FAKIR
sp.p: To the Isle of Parrots . I am just back .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: The Parrots ’ Isle !

sp.speaker: FAKIR
sp.p: Is it so very astonishing ? Am I like you , man ? A journey does n't cost a thing . I tramp just where I like .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: ClappingHow jolly for you ! Remember your promise to take me with you as your follower when I 'm well .

sp.speaker: FAKIR
sp.p: Of course , and I 'll teach you such secrets too of travelling that nothing in sea or forest or mountain can bar your way .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: What 's all this rigmarole ?

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Amal , my dear , I bow to nothing in sea or mountain ; but if the doctor joins in with this uncle of yours , then I with all my magic must own myself beaten .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: No . Uncle sha n't tell the doctor . And I promise to lie quiet ; but the day I am well , off I go with the Fakir and nothing in sea or mountain or torrent shall stand in my way .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Fie , dear child , do n't keep on harping upon going ! It makes me so sad to hear you talk so .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Tell me , Fakir , what the Parrots ’ Isle is like .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: It 's a land of wonders ; it 's a haunt of birds . There 's no man ; and they neither speak nor walk , they simply sing and they fly .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How glorious ! And it 's by some sea ?

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Of course . It 's on the sea .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And green hills are there ?

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Indeed , they live among the green hills ; and in the time of the sunset when there is a red glow on the hillside , all the birds with their green wings flock back to their nests .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: And there are waterfalls !

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Dear me , of course ; you do n't have a hill without its waterfalls . Oh , it 's like molten diamonds ; and , my dear , what dances they have ! Do n't they make the pebbles sing as they rush over them to the sea . No devil of a doctor can stop them for a moment . The birds looked upon me as nothing but a man , quite a trifling creature without wings — and they would have nothing to do with me . Were it not so I would build a small cabin for myself among their crowd of nests and pass my days counting the sea waves .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: How I wish I were a bird ! Then —

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: But that would have been a bit of a job ; I hear you 've fixed up with the dairyman to be a hawker of curds when you grow up ; I 'm afraid such business wo n't flourish among birds ; you might land yourself into serious loss .

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: Really this is too much . Between you two I shall turn crazy . Now , I 'm off .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: Has the dairyman been , Uncle ?

sp.speaker: MADHAV
sp.p: And why should n't he ? He wo n't bother his head running errands for your pet fakir , in and out among the nests in his Parrots ’ Isle . But he has left a jar of curd for you saying that he is rather busy with his niece 's wedding in the village , and he has got to order a band at Kamlipara .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: But he is going to marry me to his little niece .

sp.speaker: GAFFER
sp.p: Dear me , we are in a fix now .

sp.speaker: AMAL
sp.p: He said she would find me a lovely little bride with a pair of pearl drops in her ears and dressed in a lovely red sâree ; and in the morning she would milk with her own hands the black cow and feed me with warm milk with foam on it from a brand new earthen cruse ; and in the evenings she would carry the lamp round the cow-house , and then come and sit by me to tell me tales of Champa and his six brothers .
